name: Battery Cages
description: Housing system for egg-laying hens where multiple birds are kept in small wire cages, typically providing 300-500 cm² per bird, preventing most natural behaviors.

biological_impacts.evidence: Cages provide less than 500 cm² per bird, preventing wing spreading, walking, and turning
High rates of osteoporosis, bone fractures from inactivity
Cannot perform dust bathing, foraging, nesting, perching
biological_impacts.source: Appleby et al. (2004) Poultry Behaviour and Welfare

biological_impacts.evidence: Elevated corticosterone levels compared to free-range systems
Higher rates of feather damage and cannibalism
biological_impacts.source: Nicol et al. (2006) World's Poultry Science Journal

freedom_from_discomfort.notes: Wire flooring causes foot problems; no comfortable resting area

freedom_from_pain_injury.notes: High rates of bone fractures, foot lesions, feather damage

freedom_to_express_normal_behavior.notes: Cannot dust bathe, forage, nest, perch, or spread wings

freedom_from_fear_distress.notes: Chronic stress documented; cannot escape aggressive cage-mates

verdict_justification: Battery cages violate 4 of 5 freedoms. The practice causes documented suffering including chronic stress, skeletal disorders, behavioral deprivation, and injuries. No essential benefit justifies this level of harm (egg production can use higher-welfare systems). Per @proportionality, convenience and cost reduction do not override welfare. Per @biological_primacy, tradition and economics cannot justify suffering.
recommendations: Transition to cage-free or free-range systems
Minimum: enriched colony cages as interim improvement

alternatives.name: Cage-free barn
alternatives.limitations: Still indoor, density can be high

regulatory_status.US: Legal in most states (some state bans)

sources.citation: Lay, D.C. et al. (2011). Hen welfare in different housing systems. Poultry Science.
Webster, A.B. (2004). Welfare implications of avian osteoporosis. Animal Welfare.
EFSA (2005). Opinion on the welfare aspects of various systems of keeping laying hens. EFSA Journal.
